content: Start off your morning by exposing yourself to something positive. You want to begin the day in a good place. When you step out the door for work or school, you will be bombarded with a lot of negativity. To combat this, work on feeling good about yourself the second you wake up. [2] Look for passages from books, lines from movies, articles online, or blog posts about body and appearance positivity. You could try keeping a journal by your bed where you've written down positive messages. You can also write down positive messages on index cards. You can leave them where you're likely to see them early in the morning. For example, write down a line from a poem on body positivity and place it on your coffee pot. Identify what you love about your body. If you're insecure about your body, you probably focus mostly on what you think is wrong with it. Instead of rehearsing those same old ideas, try reframing your attention to focus on what you like about your body. [3] Are you good at sports or other physical activities? Do you have good hand-eye coordination? Has your body allowed you to pull off certain styles? Do you look really good in certain kinds of clothing? Does your body provide you with pleasure? How do you feel when you get a massage or go swimming? Take a time out from reading beauty magazines or following celebrities on social media. You need to connect with your body away from outside influences. This will help to stop comparing yourself with others and appreciate you for you. Un-follow certain celebrities on Twitter, stop checking websites such as weight loss and fashion blogs, and avoid glancing at tabloid covers in the supermarket. All of these things can contribute to negative feelings about the body. If you're having a hard time completely getting away from outside influences, try to set limits rather than completely cut it out. You could, for example, limit yourself to 2 hours of social media time each day. Try to take periodic "pop culture breaks." Turn off your television, computer, and phone a few hours a day. Try to do something that takes you away from outside influences, like reading a book or going for a walk. Body insecurity is often related to the messages that people receive through the media. Young women for example are encouraged through television and beauty publications to achieve a certain weight, skin tone, etcetera. Many of these ideals are unrealistic and harmful, considering the diversity of body types that exist in the world. [4] Identify what makes you feel insecure. Do you know why you feel so insecure about your body? Did your parents or friends pressure you into looking a certain way? Have you always idolized pop stars and other people in the media with "perfect" bodies? Were you criticized for the way your body looked when you were younger? Figure out situations and reminders that trigger your insecurities. Try to avoid such things in the future. [5] Do you have friends or acquaintances that are critical of their own bodies? If so, you may want to lessen contact with them, at least until you're feeling better about yourself. You could consider skipping lunch with the coworker that's constantly dieting, or not returning your cousin's self depreciating texts about his physical appearance. Think about times in the day when you're likely to feel insecure. Maybe you tend to feel insecure when you go to the grocery store, as your store has a lot of full length mirrors. You find yourself constantly checking your appearance in these mirrors. You could consider going to a different store. Avoid weighing yourself everyday and obsessing over your appearance in the mirror. "Checking" is common in people with body image struggles, but you can try to change these patterns. [6] This is one way to direct your attention away from negative thoughts about your body and toward more positive things in your life. [7] You should consider getting rid of your bathroom scale. If you're worried about tracking your weight, weigh yourself once a week at a gym or a drugstore that has a scale. When you go to the doctor's office, you can ask your doctor not to weigh you unless it's necessary for medical reasons. You can also ask that your doctor not tell you your weight. If you notice yourself checking your body, think about something else instead, like being at the beach or something else that helps you relax. You could also find something to distract yourself right away when you begin to obsess over your body. Take up a relaxing hobby, like knitting. Practice positive self talk. If you feel bad about yourself, you may find yourself putting yourself down a lot. You may engage in negative self-talk, which means you find yourself saying things to yourself like, "I can't believe how fat you are" throughout the day. Try to swap negative self talk with positive self talk. It may feel awkward at first, but with time being kind to yourself can help raise your sense of self worth. [8] Be aware of your thought patterns. If you've felt bad about yourself for awhile, you may put yourself down without thinking. Try to be aware of your thoughts at all times. Catch yourself when you begin thinking things like, "You're so ugly. You're so weak." Then, try replacing negative thoughts with positive ones. For example, say you're insecure because you feel your arms are too bulky looking. If you find yourself thinking, "I can't wear this top because it makes my arms look fat," stop and replace this thought with something more positive. For example, "I'm really proud of how strong my arms are." Try to see insecurity as humility. Despite your best efforts, you may still feel insecure sometimes. Some people beat themselves up for experiencing insecurity at all. Instead of feeling bad that you have body image issues, try to see the insecurity itself in a positive light. Try to think of yourself as modest instead of insecure, as this can help you feel better about yourself overall. [9] Try to think of yourself as humble. Be grateful you're able to acknowledge you have flaws and imperfections. Keep in mind, while it's okay to reframe your thoughts on insecurity, you should still work to feel better about yourself. It's good to have some humility, but intense insecurity can be unhealthy longterm. Think of your body in terms of function over form. You may be inclined to get down on yourself over your body's imperfections. Maybe you don't have a flat stomach or muscular biceps. You may not have the hair color or eye color you want. However, stop thinking of your body in terms of how it looks. Instead, be grateful for your body's ability to function. [10] Admire your body's abilities beyond physical beauty. Admire that your body is able to move, carry you, heal from injury, and endure physical activity. Set goals for yourself that have nothing to do with weight loss. Try to push your body in terms of endurance. For example, strive to be able to do 110 push-ups in a row, or to be able to run 2 miles without stopping. Accept what you dislike about your body while loving it overall. Everyone has things about their bodies they dislike. It is not realistic to expect yourself to love everything about your body at all times. However, learn to accept what you do not like without fixating on it. Be able to compartmentalize to a degree by loving your body overall, even when you know it's imperfect. [11] For example, you may dislike the way your stomach looks in a top. Think to yourself, "I don't like my stomach right now, but I like my body overall." After acknowledging you dislike your stomach, think about everything you love and appreciate about your body. Self love and appreciation are not all or nothing. It is okay to have frustrations without your body and still love the way you look overall. Forgive your body for its shortcomings. As people age, they tend to be less and less forgiving of their bodies. You may get frustrated that you're not building muscle as fast as you want, or that your legs will not slim down despite a lot of workouts. [12] Accept that your body will not always work as well as you want it to, and that you may never reach certain fitness goals. Instead of getting angry at your body, try to be understanding. Remind yourself that you are more than your body, and appreciate all the good your body does for you. Make small changes in the way you look at your body. If you get injured exercising, nurture your body and show it kindness instead of getting frustrated. Smile at yourself in the mirror when you feel upset with your body. Work out with the goal of caring for your body and improving your mental health. Working out can be healthy. It can help reduce stress and lessen symptoms of depression and anxiety, both of which can contribute to a poor body image. However, obsessing over change through weight loss and muscle building can make you feel worse about yourself. Instead of working out with specific weight loss goals, work out with the goal of nourishing your body and improving your overall mood. [13] [14] Give your body what you need when you work out. Do not push yourself to the point of strain or injury. Be kind to your body as you work out. Give yourself enough food and water to fuel your workouts, and remember your workouts are a way of caring for your body. You're allowing your body to stay strong over time. Make sure you talk to your doctor before beginning a new workout routine. You do not want to end up straining yourself. Provide your body with nourishment. Many people with low self esteem try dieting or healthy eating as a means to change their bodies. Eating right can help you feel better about yourself, but do so with the right mind frame. Think of healthy eating as a way of nourishing your body instead of a way of forcing your body to change. [15] [16] Go for a variety of healthy fruits and vegetables, as well as whole grains and lean proteins. Do not force yourself to eat low calorie diet food you do not like. Instead, eat foods that you enjoy that are prepared in a healthy manner. Use all your senses when you eat. This will allow you to better enjoy the meal, and be more aware of what you are consuming. Eat without distractions like the TV or computer. Focus in the taste and smell of your food. Listen to the noises food makes as you chew. Take in the smell of your food as you eat. Try closing your eyes as you eat to completely focus on the food you're eating. See a therapist. If you have an intense case of body insecurity, see about getting help from a professional psychotherapist. Cognitive-behavioral therapy is an effective way to improve your self-esteem surrounding your body and reduce any behavioral symptoms related to your body image, like binging or purging. [17] If physical appearance issues are affecting your quality of life, make sure that you seek professional help. Body Dysmorphic Disorder and other eating disorders are common, but serious conditions. You will require professional treatment to recover. A cognitive-behavioral therapist will help you notice the negative automatic thoughts about your body. Your therapist will help you work on ways to change your thinking patterns. CBT will also help you stop the obsessive behavior of checking. Checking occurs when you constantly check to see what you look like, how much you weigh, or other aspects of your body. You can find a therapist through your insurance or online. If you are a student, free counseling may be offered at your school. Ask whether a therapist you're considering does cognitive behavioral therapy. Talk to your doctor about medication. Some psychiatric medications, such as anti-depressants, can help if you are dealing with a serious case of body insecure or body dysmorphia. Talk to your family doctor or a psychiatrist about trying one of these drugs if you feel like medication would help you cope. [18] Make sure to tell your doctor about any other medications you are taking, so he will know about any potentially dangerous drug interactions. You may want to see a therapist and a psychiatrist while taking psychiatric medication. This can help assure the medication works effectively for you and has no negative side effects. Surround yourself with supportive people. If you're feeling poorly about yourself, support is vital. Seek out friends and family members who are positive. Try to spend time with people who feel good about their bodies and are generally positive. [19] Spend time with people who appreciate you. You want to spend time with friends and family members who encourage you to be yourself and genuinely like you. Friends who tend to be negative or jealous should be avoided when you're struggling with your self esteem. Do not be afraid to ask for help. You can ask for support by saying, "I could really use some help with these body image issues I'm struggling with. Do you think you could do your best to be there for me?" Join a supportive, body-positive community. There are a lot of online forums and in-person groups to join if you need support for your body image insecurities. These communities give an outlet for people to express their concerns and relate to others who are going through similar struggles. If you have an eating disorder or if your struggles are weight related, you can start by looking at the eating disorders section of the psychforums website: /eating-disorders/

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look">How to Feel Better About the Way You Look</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Changing_Your_Mindset_sub" id="">Changing Your Mindset</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Appreciating_Your_Amazing_Body_sub" id="">Appreciating Your Amazing Body</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Getting_Outside_Help_sub" id="">Getting Outside Help</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>. Paul Chernyak is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Chicago. He graduated from the American School of Professional Psychology in 2011.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">20 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>If you feel insecure about the way you look, you aren't alone. People are bombarded with a huge number of messages about beauty standards every year, which can easily contribute to feelings of insecurity.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> If you would like to become more confident about your body and looks, there are steps you can take to change how you think about your body. To start, work on changing your mindset. Actively work against negative thoughts and make an effort to appreciate yourself and your appearance each day. From there, work on appreciating your body. Rather than seeing your body in terms of its flaws, try to appreciate what your body can do for you. You should also seek outside help. Talk to supportive friends and family members. Let them know you're taking steps to feel better about yourself and your appearance.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Changing_Your_Mindset_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Changing_Your_Mindset">Changing Your Mindset</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_33a7f6c18c" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_33a7f6c18c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Start off your morning by exposing yourself to something positive.</b> You want to begin the day in a good place. When you step out the door for work or school, you will be bombarded with a lot of negativity. To combat this, work on feeling good about yourself the second you wake up.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Look for passages from books, lines from movies, articles online, or blog posts about body and appearance positivity. You could try keeping a journal by your bed where you've written down positive messages.</li>
<li>You can also write down positive messages on index cards. You can leave them where you're likely to see them early in the morning. For example, write down a line from a poem on body positivity and place it on your coffee pot.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_649dec331f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_649dec331f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Identify what you love about your body.</b> If you're insecure about your body, you probably focus mostly on what you think is wrong with it. Instead of rehearsing those same old ideas, try reframing your attention to focus on what you like about your body.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Are you good at sports or other physical activities? Do you have good hand-eye coordination?</li>
<li>Has your body allowed you to pull off certain styles? Do you look really good in certain kinds of clothing?</li>
<li>Does your body provide you with pleasure? How do you feel when you get a massage or go swimming?</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_89cdafad91" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_89cdafad91')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take a time out from reading beauty magazines or following celebrities on social media.</b> You need to connect with your body away from outside influences. This will help to stop comparing yourself with others and appreciate you for you. Un-follow certain celebrities on Twitter, stop checking websites such as weight loss and fashion blogs, and avoid glancing at tabloid covers in the supermarket. All of these things can contribute to negative feelings about the body.

<ul>
<li>If you're having a hard time completely getting away from outside influences, try to set limits rather than completely cut it out. You could, for example, limit yourself to 2 hours of social media time each day.</li>
<li>Try to take periodic "pop culture breaks." Turn off your television, computer, and phone a few hours a day. Try to do something that takes you away from outside influences, like reading a book or going for a walk.</li>
<li>Body insecurity is often related to the messages that people receive through the media. Young women for example are encouraged through television and beauty publications to achieve a certain weight, skin tone, etcetera. Many of these ideals are unrealistic and harmful, considering the diversity of body types that exist in the world.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_587dd3eb40" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_587dd3eb40')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Identify what makes you feel insecure.</b> Do you know why you feel so insecure about your body? Did your parents or friends pressure you into looking a certain way? Have you always idolized pop stars and other people in the media with "perfect" bodies? Were you criticized for the way your body looked when you were younger? Figure out situations and reminders that trigger your insecurities. Try to avoid such things in the future.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Do you have friends or acquaintances that are critical of their own bodies? If so, you may want to lessen contact with them, at least until you're feeling better about yourself. You could consider skipping lunch with the coworker that's constantly dieting, or not returning your cousin's self depreciating texts about his physical appearance.</li>
<li>Think about times in the day when you're likely to feel insecure. Maybe you tend to feel insecure when you go to the grocery store, as your store has a lot of full length mirrors. You find yourself constantly checking your appearance in these mirrors. You could consider going to a different store.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_064d5e2e58" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_064d5e2e58')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid weighing yourself everyday and obsessing over your appearance in the mirror.</b> "Checking" is common in people with body image struggles, but you can try to change these patterns.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> This is one way to direct your attention away from negative thoughts about your body and toward more positive things in your life.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You should consider getting rid of your bathroom scale. If you're worried about tracking your weight, weigh yourself once a week at a gym or a drugstore that has a scale. When you go to the doctor's office, you can ask your doctor not to weigh you unless it's necessary for medical reasons. You can also ask that your doctor not tell you your weight.</li>
<li>If you notice yourself checking your body, think about something else instead, like being at the beach or something else that helps you relax. You could also find something to distract yourself right away when you begin to obsess over your body. Take up a relaxing hobby, like knitting.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e8d3f0c64e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e8d3f0c64e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Practice positive self talk.</b> If you feel bad about yourself, you may find yourself putting yourself down a lot. You may engage in negative self-talk, which means you find yourself saying things to yourself like, "I can't believe how fat you are" throughout the day. Try to swap negative self talk with positive self talk. It may feel awkward at first, but with time being kind to yourself can help raise your sense of self worth.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Be aware of your thought patterns. If you've felt bad about yourself for awhile, you may put yourself down without thinking. Try to be aware of your thoughts at all times. Catch yourself when you begin thinking things like, "You're so ugly. You're so weak."</li>
<li>Then, try replacing negative thoughts with positive ones. For example, say you're insecure because you feel your arms are too bulky looking. If you find yourself thinking, "I can't wear this top because it makes my arms look fat," stop and replace this thought with something more positive. For example, "I'm really proud of how strong my arms are."</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_81e3f30d1f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_81e3f30d1f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try to see insecurity as humility.</b> Despite your best efforts, you may still feel insecure sometimes. Some people beat themselves up for experiencing insecurity at all. Instead of feeling bad that you have body image issues, try to see the insecurity itself in a positive light. Try to think of yourself as modest instead of insecure, as this can help you feel better about yourself overall.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Try to think of yourself as humble. Be grateful you're able to acknowledge you have flaws and imperfections.</li>
<li>Keep in mind, while it's okay to reframe your thoughts on insecurity, you should still work to feel better about yourself. It's good to have some humility, but intense insecurity can be unhealthy longterm.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>

<a class="anchor" name="Appreciating_Your_Amazing_Body_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Appreciating_Your_Amazing_Body">Appreciating Your Amazing Body</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_12800fa852" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_12800fa852')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Think of your body in terms of function over form.</b> You may be inclined to get down on yourself over your body's imperfections. Maybe you don't have a flat stomach or muscular biceps. You may not have the hair color or eye color you want. However, stop thinking of your body in terms of how it looks. Instead, be grateful for your body's ability to function.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Admire your body's abilities beyond physical beauty. Admire that your body is able to move, carry you, heal from injury, and endure physical activity.</li>
<li>Set goals for yourself that have nothing to do with weight loss. Try to push your body in terms of endurance. For example, strive to be able to do 110 push-ups in a row, or to be able to run 2 miles without stopping.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e7a8fcec1c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e7a8fcec1c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Accept what you dislike about your body while loving it overall.</b> Everyone has things about their bodies they dislike. It is not realistic to expect yourself to love everything about your body at all times. However, learn to accept what you do not like without fixating on it. Be able to compartmentalize to a degree by loving your body overall, even when you know it's imperfect.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, you may dislike the way your stomach looks in a top. Think to yourself, "I don't like my stomach right now, but I like my body overall." After acknowledging you dislike your stomach, think about everything you love and appreciate about your body.</li>
<li>Self love and appreciation are not all or nothing. It is okay to have frustrations without your body and still love the way you look overall.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_646587e5dc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_646587e5dc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Forgive your body for its shortcomings.</b> As people age, they tend to be less and less forgiving of their bodies. You may get frustrated that you're not building muscle as fast as you want, or that your legs will not slim down despite a lot of workouts.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Accept that your body will not always work as well as you want it to, and that you may never reach certain fitness goals. Instead of getting angry at your body, try to be understanding. Remind yourself that you are more than your body, and appreciate all the good your body does for you.</li>
<li>Make small changes in the way you look at your body. If you get injured exercising, nurture your body and show it kindness instead of getting frustrated. Smile at yourself in the mirror when you feel upset with your body.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5faa375745" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5faa375745')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Work out with the goal of caring for your body and improving your mental health.</b> Working out can be healthy. It can help reduce stress and lessen symptoms of depression and anxiety, both of which can contribute to a poor body image. However, obsessing over change through weight loss and muscle building can make you feel worse about yourself. Instead of working out with specific weight loss goals, work out with the goal of nourishing your body and improving your overall mood.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Give your body what you need when you work out. Do not push yourself to the point of strain or injury. Be kind to your body as you work out. Give yourself enough food and water to fuel your workouts, and remember your workouts are a way of caring for your body. You're allowing your body to stay strong over time.</li>
<li>Make sure you talk to your doctor before beginning a new workout routine. You do not want to end up straining yourself.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_1970cfd73f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1970cfd73f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Provide your body with nourishment.</b> Many people with low self esteem try dieting or healthy eating as a means to change their bodies. Eating right can help you feel better about yourself, but do so with the right mind frame. Think of healthy eating as a way of nourishing your body instead of a way of forcing your body to change.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Go for a variety of healthy fruits and vegetables, as well as whole grains and lean proteins. Do not force yourself to eat low calorie diet food you do not like. Instead, eat foods that you enjoy that are prepared in a healthy manner.</li>
<li>Use all your senses when you eat. This will allow you to better enjoy the meal, and be more aware of what you are consuming. Eat without distractions like the TV or computer. Focus in the taste and smell of your food. Listen to the noises food makes as you chew. Take in the smell of your food as you eat. Try closing your eyes as you eat to completely focus on the food you're eating.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
</li>
</ol>

<a class="anchor" name="Getting_Outside_Help_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_Outside_Help">Getting Outside Help</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0c747094ca" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0c747094ca')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See a therapist.</b> If you have an intense case of body insecurity, see about getting help from a professional psychotherapist. Cognitive-behavioral therapy is an effective way to improve your self-esteem surrounding your body and reduce any behavioral symptoms related to your body image, like binging or purging.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup> If physical appearance issues are affecting your quality of life, make sure that you seek professional help. Body Dysmorphic Disorder and other eating disorders are common, but serious conditions. You will require professional treatment to recover.

<ul>
<li>A cognitive-behavioral therapist will help you notice the negative automatic thoughts about your body. Your therapist will help you work on ways to change your thinking patterns.</li>
<li>CBT will also help you stop the obsessive behavior of checking. Checking occurs when you constantly check to see what you look like, how much you weigh, or other aspects of your body.</li>
<li>You can find a therapist through your insurance or online. If you are a student, free counseling may be offered at your school. Ask whether a therapist you're considering does cognitive behavioral therapy.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_68ba1b2cac" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_68ba1b2cac')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to your doctor about medication.</b> Some psychiatric medications, such as anti-depressants, can help if you are dealing with a serious case of body insecure or body dysmorphia. Talk to your family doctor or a psychiatrist about trying one of these drugs if you feel like medication would help you cope.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Make sure to tell your doctor about any other medications you are taking, so he will know about any potentially dangerous drug interactions.</li>
<li>You may want to see a therapist and a psychiatrist while taking psychiatric medication. This can help assure the medication works effectively for you and has no negative side effects.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_1d73dec042" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1d73dec042')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Surround yourself with supportive people.</b> If you're feeling poorly about yourself, support is vital. Seek out friends and family members who are positive. Try to spend time with people who feel good about their bodies and are generally positive.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Spend time with people who appreciate you. You want to spend time with friends and family members who encourage you to be yourself and genuinely like you. Friends who tend to be negative or jealous should be avoided when you're struggling with your self esteem.</li>
<li>Do not be afraid to ask for help. You can ask for support by saying, "I could really use some help with these body image issues I'm struggling with. Do you think you could do your best to be there for me?"</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=471815" href="#/Image:Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_ce1ab00dcf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ce1ab00dcf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Better About the Way You Look Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg/aid471815-v4-728px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Join a supportive, body-positive community.</b> There are a lot of online forums and in-person groups to join if you need support for your body image insecurities. These communities give an outlet for people to express their concerns and relate to others who are going through similar struggles.

<ul>
<li>If you have an eating disorder or if your struggles are weight related, you can start by looking at the eating disorders section of the psychforums website: <a class="external free" href="http://www.psychforums.com/eating-disorders/" rel="nofollow">http://www.psychforums.com/eating-disorders/</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="471815" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="293834" data-caid="294707" data-cqid="293851" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1814687" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I block out negative comments from others?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Ignore them! Just recognize that you can't please everybody no matter what you do or what you look like, so there's no point in focusing on what other people want or expect. Just live your life how you want to and let the negativity slide off you. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="472036" data-caid="472909" data-cqid="472053" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2511577" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Despite millions of facials, hairdresser appointments brow appointments, mani and pedis, and extensions for the hair, I still feel ugly. What can I do next?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>

</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You are beautiful. Once you start accepting who you are your inner beauty will  shine through. </div>

<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_ask_heading">Ask a Question</div>
<div id="qa_submitted_question_form">
<input id="qa_asked_question" maxlength="200" placeholder="What do you need to know? We'll do our best to find the answer." type="text"/><div id="qa_asked_count">200 characters left</div>
<input id="qa_email" placeholder="Email address (optional)" type="text"/><div id="qa_email_prompt">Include your email address to get a message when this question is answered.</div>
<a class="button primary" id="qa_submit_button">Submit</a>
</div>
<!--  Template for rendering a submitted question -->
<script id="qa_submitted_question_item" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<li class="qa_sq" data-sqid="{{id}}">
	<div class="qa_divider"></div>
	<div class="qa_li_container">
		<div class="qa_bullet"></div>
		<div class="qa_sq_question">
			<div class="qa_q_txt">{{{text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_editor_tools">
				<a class="qa_edit_submitted {{#qa_desktop}}button secondary{{/qa_desktop}}">{{qa_curate}}</a>
				{{^mobile_anon_user}}
				<a class="qa_flag_submitted" data-type="sq_flag">{{qa_flag}}</a>
				<a class="qa_ignore_submitted" data-type="sq_ignore">{{qa_ignore}}</a>
				{{/mobile_anon_user}}
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

			</script><!--  Template for answer confirmation  --><script id="qa_answer_confirmation" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_answer_confirmation">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div class="qa_answer_confirmation_response">
		<span class="qa_checkmark"></span>
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading standalone">{{qa_proposed_answer_confirmation}}</div>
	</div>

</div>


			</script><!--  Template form for creating/updating a curated question  --><script id="qa_question_edit_form" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_aq_edit_form">
	<div class="qa_aq_edit_form_status"></div>
	<textarea class="qa_cq_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_question_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_question}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_cq_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_cq_text_error}}</div>
	<textarea class="qa_ca_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_answer_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_answer}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_error}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error2 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_min}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error3 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_url}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error_phone qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_phone}}</div>
	<input class="qa_pa_email" placeholder="{{qa_pa_email_placeholder}}"/>

	{{#qa_admin}}
		<span class="qa_edit_form_verifier_container">
			{{qa_edit_form_verifier_label}}
			<select class="qa_edit_form_verifier">
				{{#qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
					<option value="{{id}}" {{selected}}>{{name}}</option>
				{{/qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
			</select>
		</span>
		{{#qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}
		<span class="qa_edit_form_remove_submitter_container">
			<label for="qa_aq_remove_submitter">{{qa_edit_form_remove_submitter}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_remove_submitter" class="qa_checkbox" />
		</span>
		{{/qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}
	{{/qa_admin}}

	<span class="qa_edit_form_inactive_container">
		<label for="qa_aq_inactive">{{qa_edit_form_inactive}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_inactive" class="qa_checkbox" {{qa_edit_form_inactive_val}}>
	</span>

	<div class="clearall"></div>

	{{#qa_admin}}<a class="qa_aq_delete button primary">{{qa_edit_form_delete}}</a>{{/qa_admin}}
	<a class="qa_aq_submit button primary">{{qa_edit_form_submit}}</a>
	<span class="qa_spinner"></span>
	<a class="qa_aq_cancel button secondary">{{qa_edit_form_cancel}}</a>
</div>

			</script><!--  Template for the social login/signup form  --><script id="qa_social_login_form" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_social_login_form">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div>
		<span class="qa_checkmark"></span>
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading">{{qa_thanks_for_answer}}</div>
	</div>

	<div style="clear: both;"></div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_body">{{qa_social_login_form_cta}}</div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_button_container">
		<div class="qa_button social_login_button facebook_button">
			<span class="social_login_button_icon"></span>
			<span class="social_login_button_text">Facebook</span>
		</div>
		<div class="qa_button social_login_button google_button">
			<span class="social_login_button_icon"></span>
			<span class="social_login_button_text">Google</span>
		</div>
	</div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_sub">{{qa_social_login_disclaimer}}</div>

</div>

			</script><!--  Template for social login/signup confirmation  --><script id="qa_social_login_confirmation" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_social_login_confirmation">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div>
		<img src="{{avatarUrl}}" class="qa_social_login_avatar" alt="user avatar">
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading">{{qa_thanks_for_social_login}}</div>
	</div>

	<div style="clear: both;"></div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_body">{{qa_info_after_social_login}}</div>

	<a class="qa_social_login_done button primary">Done</a>

</div>


			</script><div data-type="" id="qa_flag_options">
<div class="hint_box">
<ul>
<li><a data-option="answered" href="#">Already answered</a></li>
<li><a data-option="not_question" href="#">Not a question</a></li>
<li><a data-option="bad_question" href="#">Bad question</a></li>
<li><a data-option="other" href="#">Other</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div data-type="" id="qa_answer_flag_options">
<div class="hint_box">
<ul></ul>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Template for rendering a desktop ArticleQuestion -->
<script id="qa_article_question_item" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
			<li class="qa_aq qa_block {{#inactive}}qa_inactive{{/inactive}}" data-aqid="{{id}}" data-cqid="{{curatedQuestion.id}}" data-caid="{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.id}}" data-sqid="{{curatedQuestion.submittedId}}" data-qa_inactive="{{inactive}}" data-votes_up="{{votesUp}}" data-votes_down="{{votesDown}}" data-verifier_id="{{verifierId}}" data-submitter_id="{{submitterUserId}}">
	<div class="qa_divider"></div>

	<div class="qa_li_container">
		<div class="qa_question_tab">{{qa_question_label}}</div>
		<div class="qa_q_txt{{#qa_desktop}} question{{/qa_desktop}}">{{{curatedQuestion.text}}}</div>
		{{#qa_staff}}<div class="qa_staff_info">{{staffInfo}}</div>{{/qa_staff}}

		{{#show_editor_tools}}
		<div class="qa_editor_tools">
			<a class="qa_edit_aq">{{qa_edit}}</a>
		</div>
		{{/show_editor_tools}}

		<div class="qa_answers">
			<div class="{{qa_answerer_class}}">
			{{#qa_desktop}}
				<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">{{#verifierId}}{{> qa_expert_hover}}{{/verifierId}}</div>
			{{/qa_desktop}}

				<div class="qa_badge"></div>

			{{#verifierId}}
				<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" target="_blank" {{#verifierData.imagePath}}style="background-image: url({{verifierData.imagePath}})"{{/verifierData.imagePath}}>
					{{^verifierData.imagePath}}<span>{{verifierData.initials}}</span>{{/verifierData.imagePath}}</a>
			{{/verifierId}}

			{{^verifierId}}
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#submitterAvatar}}style="background-image:url({{{submitterAvatar}}})"{{/submitterAvatar}}></div>
			{{/verifierId}}

				<div class="qa_answerer_info">
				{{#verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">
						<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" target="_blank">{{verifierData.name}}</a>
					</div>
					<div class="qa_user_title">{{{verifierData.blurb}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				{{^verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">{{{submitterDisplayName}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

					<div class="qa_user_label">{{qa_answerer_label}}</div>
					{{#isTopAnswerer}}{{^qa_desktop}}<div class="qa_ta_mobile_extra"></div>{{/qa_desktop}}{{/isTopAnswerer}}
				</div>
			</div>

		{{#qa_desktop}}
			<div class="qa_answer answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_answer_footer">
				{{> thumbs_qa_widget}}
				{{^qa_anon}}
				<a class="qa_ignore_answered" href="#">{{qa_flag_duplicate}}</a>
				<p class="qa_ignore_answered_thanks">Thanks!</p>
				{{/qa_anon}}
			</div>
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		{{^qa_desktop}}
		<ul>
			<li class="qa_answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</li>
		</ul>
		{{> thumbs_up_down}}
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

		</script><!-- Template for rendering an unpatrolled QA --><!--  Template form for desktop thumbs up/down functionality  --><script id="qa_thumbs_qa_widget" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
	<span class='wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg'>{{thumbs_response}}</span>
	<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary">{{qa_thumbs_yes}}</a>
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary">{{qa_thumbs_no}}</a>
	</div>
	<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box">{{qa_thumbs_nohelp}} <span>{{votesDown}}</span></a>
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box">{{qa_thumbs_help}} <span>{{votesUp}}</span></a>
	</div>
</div>



			</script><!--  Template for rendering a Top Answerers data --><script id="top_answerers_qa_widget" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#ta_image}}style="background-image:url({{{ta_image}}})"{{/ta_image}}></div>
<div class='qa_ta_name'>
	<span><a href="{{userLink}}" class="sp_namelink" target="_blank">{{userName}}</a>, {{ta_label}}</span><br />
	{{answersCount}} {{ta_answers_label}}
</div>
<div class="qa_ta_cats">
{{#topCats.0}}
	{{ta_subcats_intro}}
	{{#topCats}}<a href="{{cat_link}}">{{cat}}</a>, {{/topCats}}
	{{ta_subcats_outro}}
{{/topCats.0}}
</div>
			</script>
</div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>You can tackle your insecurity in multiple ways. You can be critical of society's body image standards and still make efforts to get in shape.</li>
<li>Wear clothes that make you feel comfortable and good about yourself.</li>
<li>Avoid letting your focus rest exclusively on your body image. Remember that there are other important things in life, such as your friends and loved ones.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>If you feel hopeless about your situation, try calling the National Eating Disorders helpline at 1-800-931-2237. Even if you don't have an eating disorder, you can talk to them about your body image insecurities.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To feel better about the way you look, think about the reasons why you feel insecure. For example, maybe your parents or friends pressured you into looking a certain way or you idolize pop stars with “perfect” bodies. If you often compare yourself to people in beauty magazines and social media, try taking a break from those things and spending time doing things you enjoy. Additionally, try to focus on what you love about your body. For instance, does it allow you to pull off certain styles or does it provide you with pleasure when you go swimming or get a massage? <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more tips from our Counselor co-author, including when to see a therapist about your body image, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Feel Better About the Way You Look",
    "name": "Feel Better About the Way You Look",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look"
    },

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg\/aid471815-v4-1200px-Feel-Better-About-the-Way-You-Look-Step-16.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 5,
        "ratingValue": 60
    },
    "datePublished": "2008-10-21",
    "dateModified": "2019-04-26",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Paul Chernyak, LPC"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Changing Your Mindset",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Start off your morning by exposing yourself to something positive. You want to begin the day in a good place. When you step out the door for work or school, you will be bombarded with a lot of negativity. To combat this, work on feeling good about yourself the second you wake up.[2]\nLook for passages from books, lines from movies, articles online, or blog posts about body and appearance positivity. You could try keeping a journal by your bed where you've written down positive messages.\nYou can also write down positive messages on index cards. You can leave them where you're likely to see them early in the morning. For example, write down a line from a poem on body positivity and place it on your coffee pot."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Identify what you love about your body. If you're insecure about your body, you probably focus mostly on what you think is wrong with it. Instead of rehearsing those same old ideas, try reframing your attention to focus on what you like about your body.[3]\nAre you good at sports or other physical activities? Do you have good hand-eye coordination?\nHas your body allowed you to pull off certain styles? Do you look really good in certain kinds of clothing?\nDoes your body provide you with pleasure? How do you feel when you get a massage or go swimming?"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Take a time out from reading beauty magazines or following celebrities on social media. You need to connect with your body away from outside influences. This will help to stop comparing yourself with others and appreciate you for you. Un-follow certain celebrities on Twitter, stop checking websites such as weight loss and fashion blogs, and avoid glancing at tabloid covers in the supermarket. All of these things can contribute to negative feelings about the body.\n\nIf you're having a hard time completely getting away from outside influences, try to set limits rather than completely cut it out. You could, for example, limit yourself to 2 hours of social media time each day.\nTry to take periodic \"pop culture breaks.\" Turn off your television, computer, and phone a few hours a day. Try to do something that takes you away from outside influences, like reading a book or going for a walk.\nBody insecurity is often related to the messages that people receive through the media. Young women for example are encouraged through television and beauty publications to achieve a certain weight, skin tone, etcetera. Many of these ideals are unrealistic and harmful, considering the diversity of body types that exist in the world.[4]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Identify what makes you feel insecure. Do you know why you feel so insecure about your body? Did your parents or friends pressure you into looking a certain way? Have you always idolized pop stars and other people in the media with \"perfect\" bodies? Were you criticized for the way your body looked when you were younger? Figure out situations and reminders that trigger your insecurities. Try to avoid such things in the future.[5]\nDo you have friends or acquaintances that are critical of their own bodies? If so, you may want to lessen contact with them, at least until you're feeling better about yourself. You could consider skipping lunch with the coworker that's constantly dieting, or not returning your cousin's self depreciating texts about his physical appearance.\nThink about times in the day when you're likely to feel insecure. Maybe you tend to feel insecure when you go to the grocery store, as your store has a lot of full length mirrors. You find yourself constantly checking your appearance in these mirrors. You could consider going to a different store."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid weighing yourself everyday and obsessing over your appearance in the mirror. \"Checking\" is common in people with body image struggles, but you can try to change these patterns.[6] This is one way to direct your attention away from negative thoughts about your body and toward more positive things in your life.[7]\nYou should consider getting rid of your bathroom scale. If you're worried about tracking your weight, weigh yourself once a week at a gym or a drugstore that has a scale. When you go to the doctor's office, you can ask your doctor not to weigh you unless it's necessary for medical reasons. You can also ask that your doctor not tell you your weight.\nIf you notice yourself checking your body, think about something else instead, like being at the beach or something else that helps you relax. You could also find something to distract yourself right away when you begin to obsess over your body. Take up a relaxing hobby, like knitting."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Practice positive self talk. If you feel bad about yourself, you may find yourself putting yourself down a lot. You may engage in negative self-talk, which means you find yourself saying things to yourself like, \"I can't believe how fat you are\" throughout the day. Try to swap negative self talk with positive self talk. It may feel awkward at first, but with time being kind to yourself can help raise your sense of self worth.[8]\nBe aware of your thought patterns. If you've felt bad about yourself for awhile, you may put yourself down without thinking. Try to be aware of your thoughts at all times. Catch yourself when you begin thinking things like, \"You're so ugly. You're so weak.\"\nThen, try replacing negative thoughts with positive ones. For example, say you're insecure because you feel your arms are too bulky looking. If you find yourself thinking, \"I can't wear this top because it makes my arms look fat,\" stop and replace this thought with something more positive. For example, \"I'm really proud of how strong my arms are.\""
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try to see insecurity as humility. Despite your best efforts, you may still feel insecure sometimes. Some people beat themselves up for experiencing insecurity at all. Instead of feeling bad that you have body image issues, try to see the insecurity itself in a positive light. Try to think of yourself as modest instead of insecure, as this can help you feel better about yourself overall.[9]\nTry to think of yourself as humble. Be grateful you're able to acknowledge you have flaws and imperfections.\nKeep in mind, while it's okay to reframe your thoughts on insecurity, you should still work to feel better about yourself. It's good to have some humility, but intense insecurity can be unhealthy longterm."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Appreciating Your Amazing Body",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Think of your body in terms of function over form. You may be inclined to get down on yourself over your body's imperfections. Maybe you don't have a flat stomach or muscular biceps. You may not have the hair color or eye color you want. However, stop thinking of your body in terms of how it looks. Instead, be grateful for your body's ability to function.[10]\nAdmire your body's abilities beyond physical beauty. Admire that your body is able to move, carry you, heal from injury, and endure physical activity.\nSet goals for yourself that have nothing to do with weight loss. Try to push your body in terms of endurance. For example, strive to be able to do 110 push-ups in a row, or to be able to run 2 miles without stopping."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
